
# SHA-256 Demonstration

This is my implementation of the SHA-256 hash algorithm in Python. This implementation is not meant to be efficient or useful, it was constructed as a way for me to learn and understand the fundamentals of SHA-256 and what makes it virtually irreversible.

## How it Works

SHA-256 is a cryptographic hash function that takes an input message and produces a fixed-size output, known as a hash. This implementation of SHA-256 works by taking an input message and performing a series of bitwise and logical operations on it to produce a 256-bit hash.

The algorithm consists of several stages, including message padding, message parsing, and round function computation. In each stage, the message is transformed in a way that makes it virtually impossible to reverse engineer the original message from the hash.

## What Makes SHA-256 Virtually Irreversible

SHA-256 is considered virtually irreversible due to the properties of cryptographic hash functions. One of the key properties of a cryptographic hash function is that it is a one-way function - it is easy to compute the hash of a message, but it is virtually impossible to reverse engineer the original message from the hash.

This is because the hash function uses operations such as XOR functions, which takes two bits as input and gives one bit as output. This means that given one bit, there are two possible scenarios that you have to test when bruteforcing. However, SHA-256 uses over 14,000 XOR operations on 32-bit blocks, which is over 448,000 of our two-bit truth table example. This creates a virtually untouchable number of branching paths that you would have to test to be able to bruteforce the original message.

## Usage

While you are not really meant to use this, run the program as follows, starting from `python3 ./main.py`.
To run the program, first clone the repository.

```
$ git clone https://github.com/polambert/sha256-demo
$ cd sha256-demo
```

Run the demonstration using `python3 main.py`. You will have to have Python 3 installed.

If you want to display the number of each type of operation SHA completes as it runs, you can change the value of "log_totals" on line 12 of sha256testlib.py to True.

```
$ python3 ./main.py
enter message to hash: hi

-----------
- Message -
-----------
  input: hi
  bytes: [104, 105]
  bin:   0110100001101001 (16 bits)

-----------
- Padding -
-----------
  message: 0110100001101001 (16 bits)
  message: 01101000011010011 (17 bits)
  message:  (448 bits)
  message:  (512 bits)
```
